Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Determination of the Optical and Reactive Properties of Water Vapor of Relevance to Atmospheric Radiation, Cloud Physics and Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is investigating water vapor absorption of near ultraviolet (NUV) solar radiation in the atmosphere. The results of this research may help resolve a long-standing discrepancy between modeled and observed solar energy absorption under clear sky conditions in the atmosphere. This research combines laboratory experiments, field measurements, and modeling to investigate critically important issues regarding the role of water vapor absorption in determining the radiative equilibrium of the atmosphere.

The objectives of the project are to make laboratory measurements of water vapor near UV absorption cross sections and their temperature dependence at spectral resolution and intervals comparable to existing satellite/surface ozone monitoring instruments, to monitor water vapor near UV spectral absorption in the tropical atmosphere, and to evaluate the consequences of including this near UV absorption by water vapor on satellite/surface ozone retrievals and on models of atmospheric radiation, circulation, and climate. Field measurements will be acquired by piggybacking a UV radiation spectrometer on the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) project, the AERosols and Ocean Science Expeditions (AEROSE) field campaign in the equatorial Atlantic. A different partitioning of atmospheric absorption by ozone and water vapor could alter model simulations of large-scale atmospheric circulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas and plays a dominant role in atmospheric radiative balance.  However, water vapor absorption in the near-UV region and the impact of such absorption on field ozone retrieval and atmospheric radiation budget are poorly understood. Without accounting for near-UV absorption by water vapor could lead to an overestimate in ozone amount, degrades the accuracy of satellite ozone measurements, leading to erroneous assessment of long-term ozone trend and ozone recovery. Furthermore, water vapor near-UV absorption may significantly impact the modeling of near-UV solar radiation on the ground and the accuracy of climate modeling. The major goals of the project are to determine water vapor near UV absorption cross sections and their temperature dependence at spectral resolution and intervals comparable to existing satellite/surface ozone monitoring instruments, to monitor water vapor near UV spectral absorption in the real atmosphere, and to evaluate the consequences of including this near UV absorption by water vapor on satellite/surface ozone retrievals and on models of atmospheric radiation, circulation, and climate.

Collaborating with our project partner, Dr. Lei Zhu, we studied the radiation effects of the radiation effects of in-lab measured water vapor absorption cross-section at 0.05 nm intervals in the 290-350 in the atmosphere and ozone retrievals. We analyzed field measured UV spectra to detect water vapor absorption over 290-350 nm region. In this project, we also refurbished an ultraviolet spectroradiometer, upgraded it with a fore-optical module, and integrated it into a trailer. This refurbished double Czerny-Turner UV spectroradiometer, with photon counting technology, can measure solar radiation spectra from 290 nm to 410 nm with high spectral resolution and high accuracy. It can operate with a step-size of 0.0005 nm and a FWHM of 0.1 nm. Through an automatically controlled elevation-azimuth sun tracker, this spectrometer can measure solar direct beam and sky radiance for given azimuth and elevation angles. This high resolution spectroradiometer can be used as a reference instrument for measuring UV radiation and monitoring atmospheric gases (O3, SO2, NO2).

To investigate water vapor absorption features in the real atmosphere, we conducted a series of field observations by using this high resolution spectroradiometer on the campus at University at Albany. We developed a residual analysis method to analyze absorption by atmospheric components and retrieve atmospheric optical depth in the UV range. During data processing, the SAO2010 solar spectrum was selected as extraterrestrial solar reference spectrum to retrieve the atmospheric optical depth. Compared to other solar reference spectra, the SAO2010 spectrum matches with the satellite SOLSTICE measurements very well in the 305-310 nm wavelength range.  The residual spectra for multiple cases have spectral features similar to that of lab determined water vapor absorption in wavelength regions (such as 307.0~308.7 nm and 312.0~313.0 nm), and the inferred ozone amount from residual analysis is comparable to the OMI TOMS retrievals. Results from multiple case studies show that the magnitude of the residual optical depth from observed UV spectra is sensitive to the atmospheric water vapor amount. For observations with WVP of 3, 13, and 19 mm, the related residual magnitude factors are 0.010, 0.017, and 0.022, respectively. In the 307.0~308.7 nm and 312.0~313.0 nm wavelength ranges, the residual and water vapor absorption spectra have similar spectral features with correlation coefficients of 0.47 and 0.65. Although multiple case studies have shown that the residual optical depth from observed UV spectra is related to the atmospheric water vapor absorption, some unresolved issues remain.  For example, the lab determined water vapor absorption optical depth spectrum has peak values in the wavelength range from 308 to 312 nm, but this peak is not shown in the residual optical depth spectrum. To resolve this issue, higher accuracy solar reference spectrum or ozone absorption coefficients are needed.
